description: The TK-3 tankette comprises most of the Polish armoured
forces in 1939. Originally developed in 1930, it is far
outclassed by most modern tanks but in the defense of Poland
it is being widely deployed as part of infantry and cavalry
companies.
The TKS tankette is an advanced version of the TK-3 designed in
1933, with an improved hull, suspention, and a Polish-built Fiat
engine.
The TKS tankette is an advanced version of the TK-3 designed in
1933, with an improved hull, suspention, and a Polish-built Fiat
engine. This version is rare variant armed with a 20mm gun.
First developed during the Great War, the Renault FT was the world's
first modern tank. By the outbreak of the Second World War several
thousand were still in use throughout the world.
First built in 1928, the Vickers Mark E was designed in Britain
but all production models were licensed and built abroad. This is
a Type B model, with a single turret mounting a short-barreled
47mm gun.
The design of the 7TP (7-tonne Polish) tank was based upon the
the British Vickers Mark E, but this design is more advanced and
better armed. It is, however, still a light tank, and is vulnerable
to anti-tank fire.
Produced under license from the Italian Fiat company, the 621
serves as the workhorse of the Polish military, transporting
soldiers, supplies, and even light tanks around the country.
An armoured steam locomotive, designed to move an armoured train.
This armoured railroad car mounts two 75mm guns, each in a separate
turret. Although it is limited to travel on rails, it is well-protected
and armed.
First designed in 1934, the Panzer II was always intended to be
a stop-gap solution until other planned models of medium tank could
be designed and built. Even so, it has proved to be a highly capable
light tank. This version entered production in 1937 and carries a
20mm gun as its main armament.
The LT-35 was originally built in Czechoslovakia, but over 200 vehicles
were seized by Germany in March 1939 and it entered German service
as the Panzerkampfwagen 35(t). Compared to most other light tanks
of 1939 it is well-armoured and carries a powerful 37mm main gun.
The LT-38 was designed in Czechoslovakia, and after Germany occupied
the country in March 1939 it entered production as the
Panzerkampfwagen 38(t). This model A of the light tank is armed
with a long-barreled 37mm main gun.
First designed in 1934, the Panzer III was intended to be the main
battle tank of the German armoured forces. The D model is a prototype
model and only a very small number ever entered service.
The model F of the Panzer III is the first model to enter mass
production. It is intended to serve the main battle tank of the
German armoured forces in 1939 but supplies remain limited.
The Kfz 13 was converted from an Adler touring car in 1935. Although
lightly armoured, the vehicle is completely open on its top.
The Sd.Kfz.221 was designed in secret as an all-terrain armoured
car, to replace the more limited Kfz.13. Although it is fast and
has an excellent operational range, its off-road capabilities are
fairly limited.
The Sd.Kfz. 231 was initially designed in the early 1930s, intended
for scouting operations. Based on a civilian truck chassis, the
heavy armoured car proved excellent on dry ground but lacked true
off-road capability. Although production ended in 1937, units continue
to be deployed in reconnaissance roles.
The poor off-road performance of the 6-wheeled Sd.Kfz. 231
prompted the development of this model, which placed the engine
at the rear and gave the driver better visability. Production
began in 1937 but 6-wheeled units continue to be deployed in
reconnaissance roles.
Initially designed as a heavy anti-aircraft gun, the '88'
was quicky pressed into service as an anti-tank gun, a role
in which it excelled.
The Blitz truck, produced by the General Motors subsidiary
company Opel, provides the motorized transport backbone for
the German army. The 3-ton variant is the most common variant
in use.
This 4.5-ton truck is the workhorse of the German armed forces.
It combines a reliable diesel engine with good rough terrain performance.
The T-26 tank was developed based on the British Vickers 6-ton
design, and are by far the most numerous tank in Soviet forces.
The BT-5 tank was designed to move quickly, in order to exploit
holes in enemy defensive lines.
The BT-7 tank was based on the design of the BT-5, with better front
armour, and a new engine and drive train.
The T-28 was the first of a series of 'land battleship' tanks,
intended as an infantry support tank and to break through enemy
defenses.
Designed in 1933 as a light infantry support tank, the Hotchkiss H35
was eventually adopted by the French cavalry as a light reconnaisance tank.
This early variant has a short main gun and an underpowered engine.
First designed in 1940, the M4 'Sherman' tank entered production
in 1942 and became the main battle tank for Allied forces in the
war. This is the welded hull design with a vision cupola for the
commander.
The M4A1 was the first revision of the M4 design, but it ended up
entering production first in February 1942. It has a rounded, cast
hull, giving it extra protection on the front. This version has a
vision cupola for the commander.
The M4A3 has a welded hull and carries a powerful Ford GAA V8 engine.
It ended up being the most commonly used model in the American forces.
This version has a vision cupola for the commander.
